question: Question 1-07/10/2023 The effective neutron multiplication factor, Keff, is defined as:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, page 8.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, page 8.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, page 8.
Correct

question: Question 2-07/10/2023 The reactor supervisor tells you that the K_eff for the reactor is 0.955. How much reactivity must you add to the reactor to reach criticality?

answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 4-07/10/2023 Which ONE of the following describes the factors that have the greatest effect on the fast fission factor (Ɛ)?

answers.answer: a. Enrichment of the fuel and temperature of the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, 2nd sentence of the 2nd paragraph, page 3.

answers.answer: b. Arrangement of the fuel and temperature of the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, 2nd sentence of the 2nd paragraph, page 3.

answers.answer: c. Enrichment and concentration of the fuel and the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, 2nd sentence of the 2nd paragraph, page 3.

answers.answer: d. Arrangement and concentrations of the fuel and the moderator.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 5-07/10/2023 For higher neutron energies - What is the region of the absorption cross section steadily decreases as the energy of the neutron increases called

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 1, Module 2, 3rd paragraph, page 10.
Correct

answers.answer: c. Increases the mass of the target region.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 1, Module 2, 3rd paragraph, page 10.

answers.answer: d. Destruction the mass of the target region.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 1, Module 2, 3rd paragraph, page 10.

question: Question 6-07/10/2023 In an elastic scattering reaction between a neutron and a target nucleus, there is _____ into nuclear excitation.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE, Vol. 1, Module 1, Elastic Scattering, page 43.
Correct

answers.answer: c. The nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE, Vol. 1, Module 1, Elastic Scattering, page 43.

answers.answer: d. The nucleus recoil with a higher total kinetic energy.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE, Vol. 1, Module 1, Elastic Scattering, page 43.

question: Question 7-07/10/2023 Xenon-135 is formed directly by decay of __________?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Figure 8.1, page 8-6.
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Figure 8.1, page 8-6.
Correct
Incorrect. REF: xBurn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Figure 8.1, page 8-6.xx

question: Question 8-07/10/2023 Reactor power is rising on a 10 second period. Approximately how long will it take for power to quadruple?

answers.feedback: Correct
Incorrect. REF: P = P0 et/T ––> ln(4) = time ÷ 10 seconds –> time = ln (4) x 10 sec. 1.386 x 10 ≈ 13.8 sec.
Incorrect. REF: P = P0 et/T ––> ln(4) = time ÷ 10 seconds –> time = ln (4) x 10 sec. 1.386 x 10 ≈ 13.8 sec.
Incorrect. REF: P = P0 et/T ––> ln(4) = time ÷ 10 seconds –> time = ln (4) x 10 sec. 1.386 x 10 ≈ 13.8 sec.

question: Question 9-07/10/2023 A reactor is slightly supercritical with the following values for each of the factors in the six-factor formula: Fast Fission Factor = 1.03 Fast non-leakage probability = 0.84 Resonance Escape Probability = 0.96 Thermal non-leakage probability = 0.88 Thermal Utilization Factor = 0.70 Reproduction Factor = 1.96 A control rod is inserted to bring the reactor back to critical. Assuming all other factors remain unchanged, the new value for the Thermal Utilization Factor is:

answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 10-07/10/2023 Which one of the following is the correct reason that delayed neutrons allow the reactor operator control of the reactor?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons increase the mean neutron lifetime.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. More delayed neutrons are produced than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Standard NRC Question.

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons take longer to thermalize than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Standard NRC Question.

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Standard NRC Question.

question: Question 11-07/10/2023 Which term is described by the following? 'The time from birth of a neutron to absorption and is the sum of slowing down time and diffusion time.'

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 3.3.5, page 3-23
Correct
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 3.3.5, page 3-23
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 3.3.5, page 3-23

question: Question 12-07/10/2023 You're increasing reactor power on a steady +52 second period. How long will it take to increase power by a factor of 10?

answers.feedback: Correct
Incorrect. REF: P=P_0e^t/T t=ℓn(P/P_0)*T = ℓn(10)*52 = 119.7 seconds ≈ 120 seconds = 2 minutes.
Incorrect. REF: P=P_0e^t/T t=ℓn(P/P_0)*T = ℓn(10)*52 = 119.7 seconds ≈ 120 seconds = 2 minutes.
Incorrect. REF: P=P_0e^t/T t=ℓn(P/P_0)*T = ℓn(10)*52 = 119.7 seconds ≈ 120 seconds = 2 minutes.

question: Question 13-07/10/2023 The Prompt Neutron generation time is approximately:

answers.feedback: Correct
Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 1, NP-02, page 32.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 1, NP-02, page 32.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 1, NP-02, page 32.

question: Question 14-07/10/2023 A reactor is changing from the criticality to prompt criticality. Which ONE of the following best describes the values of Keff and ρ during the change?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 4.2
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 4.2
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 4.2
Correct

question: Question 15-07/10/2023 Reactivity is defined as the:

answers.answer: a. Fractional change in neutron population per generation.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: b. Number of neutrons by which neutron population changes per generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 1.3.1, page 1-5.

answers.answer: c. Rate of change of reactor power in neutron per second.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 1.3.1, page 1-5.

answers.answer: d. Change in the number of neutrons per second that causes a fission event.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, Sec 1.3.1, page 1-5.

question: Question 16-07/10/2023 The reactor is at 5 watts, when someone inserts an experiment which causes a 10 second positive period. If the scram delay time is 1 second and the lowest scram setpoint is 9.7 watts, which ONE of the following is the MAXIMUM power the reactor will reach prior to scramming?

answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 17-07/10/2023 The reaction _93Np^239 → _94Pu^239 + ...is an example of:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Vol-01, pg. 24.
Correct
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Vol-01, pg. 24.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Vol-01, pg. 24.

question: Question 18-07/10/2023 Some neutrons do not come directly from fission, but from fission product decay. These neutrons are called:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 3.2. 2.
Correct
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 3.2. 2.
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 3.2. 2.

question: Question 19-07/10/2023 INELASTIC SCATTERING is the process by which a neutron collides with a nucleus and ...

answers.answer: a. Is absorbed, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 2-28.

answers.answer: b. Recoils with the same kinetic energy it had prior to the collision.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 2-28.

answers.answer: c. Is absorbed, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray, and the neutron with a lower kinetic energy.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. Recoils with a higher kinetic energy than it had prior to the collision with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 2-28.

question: Question 20-07/10/2023 Which ONE of the following is the principal source of heat in the reactor after a shutdown from an extended 100kW operation?

answers.feedback: Correct
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Vol-01, Module 1, EO 4.9, page 61.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Vol-01, Module 1, EO 4.9, page 61.

answers.answer: d. Subcritical reaction of photo neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Vol-01, Module 1, EO 4.9, page 61.
